etymologies: Old English rinnan, irnan (verb), of Germanic origin, probably reinforced in Middle English by Old Norse rinna, renna. The current form with -u- in the present tense is first recorded in the 16th century

notes.text: On the use of verbs used with and instead of a to infinitive, as in run and fetch the paper, see and

definitions: move at a speed faster than a walk, never having both or all the feet on the ground at the same time

examples.text: the dog ran across the road
she ran the last few yards, breathing heavily
he hasn't paid for his drinks—run and catch him

shortDefinitions: move at speed faster than walk, never having both or all feet on ground at same time

definitions: run as a sport or for exercise

examples.text: I run every morning

shortDefinitions: run as sport or for exercise

definitions: (of an athlete or a racehorse) compete in a race

examples.text: she ran in the 200 meters
Dave has run 42 marathons

shortDefinitions: (of athlete or racehorse) compete in race

definitions: enter (a racehorse) for a race.
shortDefinitions: enter racehorse for race

definitions: move about in a hurried and hectic way

examples.text: I've spent the whole day running around after the kids

shortDefinitions: move about in hurried and hectic way

definitions: (of a batter or base runner) attempt to advance to the next base.
shortDefinitions: (of batsman) run from one wicket to other in scoring or attempting to score run

definitions: (of hounds) chase or hunt their quarry

examples.text: the hounds are running

shortDefinitions: (of hounds) chase or hunt their quarry

definitions: (of a boat) sail directly before the wind, especially in bad weather

examples.text: we slanted across to the far bank and ran before the wind

shortDefinitions: (of boat) sail straight and fast directly before wind

definitions: (of a migratory fish) go upriver from the sea in order to spawn.
shortDefinitions: (of migratory fish) go upriver from sea

definitions: pass or cause to pass quickly or smoothly in a particular direction

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

examples.text: the rumor ran through the pack of photographers

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

examples.text: Helen ran her fingers through her hair

shortDefinitions: pass or cause to pass quickly in particular direction

definitions: move or cause to move somewhere forcefully or with a particular result

examples.text: the tanker ran aground off the Aleutian Islands
a woman ran a stroller into the back of my legs

shortDefinitions: move or cause to move forcefully or with particular result

definitions: fail to stop at (a red traffic light)

examples.text: cameras triggered by cars running red lights at intersections

shortDefinitions: fail to stop at

definitions: navigate (rapids or a waterfall) in a boat

examples.text: the boats were preparing to run the big rapids

shortDefinitions: navigate rapids or waterfall in boat

definitions: (with reference to a liquid) flow or cause to flow

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

examples.text: a small river runs into the sea at one side of the castle
she ran cold water into the sink

shortDefinitions: flow or cause to flow

definitions: cause water to flow over (something)

examples.text: I ran my hands under the faucet

shortDefinitions: cause water to flow over

definitions: fill (a bath) with water

examples.text: she ran a bath and lowered herself into the water
I'll run you a nice hot bath

shortDefinitions: fill bath with water

definitions: emit or exude a liquid

examples.text: she was weeping loudly, and her nose was running

shortDefinitions: emit or exude liquid

definitions: (of a solid substance) melt and become fluid

examples.text: it was so hot that the butter ran

shortDefinitions: melt and become fluid

definitions: (of the sea, the tide, or a river) rise higher or flow more quickly

examples.text: there was still a heavy sea running

shortDefinitions: rise higher or flow more quickly

definitions: (of dye or color in fabric or paper) dissolve and spread when the fabric or paper becomes wet

examples.text: the red dye ran when the socks were washed

shortDefinitions: run arudissolve and spread when fabric or paper becomes wet

definitions: extend or cause to extend in a particular direction

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

examples.text: cobbled streets run down to a tiny harbor

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

examples.text: he ran a wire under the carpet

shortDefinitions: extend or cause to extend in particular direction

definitions: pass into or reach a specified state or level

examples.text: inflation is running at 11 percent
the decision ran counter to previous government commitments

shortDefinitions: pass into or reach specified state or level

definitions: (of a bus, train, ferry, or other form of transportation) make a regular journey on a particular route

examples.text: buses run into town every half hour

shortDefinitions: make regular journey on particular route

definitions: put (a particular form of public transportation) in service

examples.text: the group is drawing up plans to run trains on key routes

shortDefinitions: put form of public transport in service

definitions: take (someone) somewhere in a car

examples.text: I'll run you home

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: take someone somewhere in car

definitions: be in charge of; manage

examples.text: Andrea runs her own catering business
an attractive family-run hotel

shortDefinitions: be in charge of

definitions: (of a system, organization, or plan) operate or proceed in a particular way

examples.text: everything's running according to plan

shortDefinitions: operate or proceed in particular way

definitions: organize and make available for other people

examples.text: we decided to run a series of seminars

shortDefinitions: organize, implement, or carry out

definitions: own, maintain, and use (a vehicle)

examples.text: he could no longer afford to run a car

shortDefinitions: own, maintain, and use

definitions: be in or cause to be in operation; function or cause to function

examples.text: the car runs on unleaded fuel
a number of peripherals can be run off one SCSI port

shortDefinitions: be in or cause to be in operation

definitions: move or cause to move between the spools of a recording machine

examples.text: I ran the tape back
the tape has run out

shortDefinitions: move between spools of recording machine

definitions: continue or be valid or operative for a particular period of time

examples.text: the course ran for two days
this particular debate will run on and on

shortDefinitions: continue or be valid or operative for particular period of time

definitions: happen or arrive at the specified time

examples.text: the program was running fifteen minutes late

shortDefinitions: happen or arrive at specified time

definitions: (of a play or exhibition) be staged or presented

examples.text: the play ran on Broadway last year

shortDefinitions: (of play or exhibition) be staged or presented

definitions: be a candidate in a political election

examples.text: he announced that he intended to run for President

shortDefinitions: stand as candidate in election

definitions: (especially of a political party) sponsor (a candidate) in an election

examples.text: they ran their first candidate for the school board

shortDefinitions: sponsor candidate in election

definitions: publish or be published in a newspaper or magazine

examples.text: the tabloids ran the story
when the story ran, there was a big to-do

shortDefinitions: publish or be published in newspaper or magazine

definitions: (of a story, argument, or piece of writing) have a specified wording or contents

examples.text: “Tapestries slashed!” ran the dramatic headline

shortDefinitions: have specified wording

definitions: bring (goods) into a country illegally and secretly; smuggle

examples.text: they run drugs for the cocaine cartels

shortDefinitions: bring goods into country illegally

definitions: (of an object or act) cost (someone) (a specified amount)

examples.text: a new photocopier will run us about $1,300

shortDefinitions: cost someone

definitions: (of a stocking or pair of tights) develop a vertical line of unraveled stitches.
shortDefinitions: develop ladder

phrases.text: give someone or something a run for their money
have a run for one's money

notes.text: On the use of verbs used with and instead of a to infinitive, as in run and fetch the paper, see and

definitions: an act or spell of running

examples.text: I usually go for a run in the morning
a cross-country run

shortDefinitions: act or spell of running

definitions: a running pace

examples.text: Bobby set off at a run

shortDefinitions: running pace

definitions: an annual mass migration of fish up a river to spawn, or their return migration afterward

examples.text: the annual salmon runs

shortDefinitions: annual mass migration of fish

definitions: a journey accomplished or route taken by a vehicle, aircraft, or boat, especially on a regular basis

examples.text: the New York-Washington run

shortDefinitions: journey accomplished or route taken by vehicle, aircraft, or boat

definitions: a short excursion made in a car

examples.text: we could take a run out to the country

shortDefinitions: short excursion made in car

definitions: the distance covered in a specified period, especially by a ship

examples.text: a record run of 398 miles from noon to noon

shortDefinitions: distance covered in specified period

definitions: a short flight made by an aircraft on a straight and even course at a constant speed before or while dropping bombs

examples.text: bombing runs by B52s

shortDefinitions: short flight made by aircraft on straight and even course

definitions: an opportunity or attempt to achieve something

examples.text: their absence means the Russians will have a clear run at the title

shortDefinitions: opportunity or attempt to achieve something

definitions: a preliminary test of the efficiency of a procedure or system

examples.text: if you are styling your hair yourself, have a practice run

shortDefinitions: preliminary test of procedure or system

definitions: an attempt to secure election to political office

examples.text: his run for the Republican nomination

shortDefinitions: attempt to secure election to political office

definitions: a continuous spell of a particular situation or condition

examples.text: he's had a run of bad luck

shortDefinitions: continuous spell of particular situation or condition

definitions: a continuous series of performances

examples.text: the play had a long run on Broadway

shortDefinitions: continuous series of performances

definitions: a quantity or amount of something produced at one time

examples.text: a production run of only 150 cars

shortDefinitions: quantity or amount of something produced at one time

definitions: a continuous stretch or length of something

examples.text: long runs of copper piping

shortDefinitions: continuous stretch or length of something

definitions: a rapid series of musical notes forming a scale.
shortDefinitions: rapid series of musical notes forming scale

definitions: a sequence of cards of the same suit.
shortDefinitions: sequence of cards of same suit

definitions: a widespread and sudden or continuous demand for (a particular currency or commodity)

examples.text: there's been a big run on nostalgia toys this year

shortDefinitions: widespread and sudden demand for commodity

definitions: a sudden demand for repayment from (a bank) made by a large number of lenders

examples.text: growing nervousness among investors led to a run on some banks

shortDefinitions: sudden demand for repayment from bank made by large number of lenders

definitions: the average or usual type of person or thing

examples.text: she stood out from the general run of varsity cheerleaders

shortDefinitions: average or usual type of person or thing

definitions: a sloping snow-covered course or track used for skiing, bobsledding, or tobogganing

examples.text: a ski run

shortDefinitions: course or track used for skiing or tobogganing

definitions: a track made or regularly used by a particular animal

examples.text: a badger run

shortDefinitions: track made or regularly used by particular animal

definitions: an enclosed area in which domestic animals or birds can run freely in the open

examples.text: a chicken run

shortDefinitions: enclosed area in which domestic animals or birds may run freely in open

definitions: a large open stretch of land used for pasture or the raising of stock

examples.text: one of the richest cattle runs of the district

shortDefinitions: large open stretch of land used for pasture

definitions: free and unrestricted use of or access to

examples.text: her cats were given the run of the house

shortDefinitions: free and unrestricted use of or access to

definitions: a point scored by hitting the ball so that both batsmen are able to run between the wickets, or awarded in some other circumstances.
shortDefinitions: unit of cricket scoring

definitions: a point scored when a base runner reaches home plate after touching the other bases.
shortDefinitions: baseball point scored by batter

definitions: a vertical line of unraveled stitches in stockings or tights

examples.text: she had a run in her nylons

shortDefinitions: ladder in stockings or tights

definitions: a downward trickle of paint or a similar substance when applied too thickly

examples.text: varnish should be applied with care to avoid runs and an uneven surface

shortDefinitions: downward trickle of paint

definitions: a small stream

examples.text: a shallow run at the edge of a low rock

shortDefinitions: small stream

definitions: diarrhoea.
shortDefinitions: diarrhoea

definitions: the after part of a ship's bottom where it rises and narrows toward the stern.
shortDefinitions: after part of ship's bottom where it rises and narrows towards stern

phrases.text: give someone or something a run for their money
have a run for one's money
